wikipedia_page.main: Captain William Charles Braxton Sinclair FRIBA (1883 – 29 November 1962) was a British architect who worked in the United Kingdom and in Burma, where he was a captain in the Royal Engineers. He was also a local historian.

link_mentions.page: First Church of Christ, Scientist, Richmond
response: It was built between 1939 and 1953; the architects were W. Braxton Sinclair (who also designed the Grade II listed First Church of Christ Scientist in Bromley) and Barton. Bridget Cherry and Nikolaus Pevsner describe it as having "heavily modelled red brickwork, with some free Baroque details".

The shelter was designed to hold 48 people and, according to the Environment Trust, was built in 1938 and extended in 1941. It has four rooms (two for men and two for women, separated by a central corridor) and a particularly well-preserved interior with some original fittings. According to Historic England, it has some similarities to W. Braxton Sinclair's design of a sophisticated air raid shelter for flats at Queen's Gate, in South Kensington, London,  which was published in The Builder in October 1938.
File:Christian_Science_Church,_Widmore_Road.jpg|A Christian Science church on Widmore Road, built by W. Braxton Sinclair in 1928 and listed at grade II
